title-group.article-title: On the Propagation of Errors in the Inversion of Certain Tridiagonal Matrices

abstract.p: When the differential equation of heat conduction is replaced by the implicit difference analog, one is led to the solution of A y = b where A is a tridiagonal matrix whose elements on the principal diagonal are = 2 + 2r and whose elements off the principal diagonal are = - r. The system of equations may be solved by the following algorithm: \begin{equation*}\begin{split} \beta_k = u = r^2 \beta^{-1}_{k-1}, \beta_1 = u_1; \quad \gamma_k = -r\beta^{-1}; \quad z_k = (b_k + rz_{k-1})\beta^{-1}_k, z_1 = b_1u^{-1}; \\ y_k = z_k - \gamma_ky_{k+1}, \quad y_M = z_M. \end{split}\end{equation*} An upper bound of the round-off errors in the computed values of the y<sub>k</sub>'s is obtained. An actual test case showed that the theoretical upper bound is about four times larger than the true round-off error. Moreover, the theoretical upper bound does not seem to vary appreciably with r.
